title: What Jurgen Klopp said about Sir Alex Ferguson as he builds Liverpool 'in his image'
text:

There is never any love lost when Manchester United face Liverpool, but there has always been a healthy dose of respect between United legend Sir Alex Ferguson and current Reds boss Jurgen Klopp.

Ferguson admitted that he was "worried" that Klopp was going to achieve good things with the Merseysiders back in 2016, and it safe to say that the German has proven him right now he's won the Champions League.

Klopp's current Reds side has often been compared to one of Ferguson's great United sides - with their emphasis on attacking with Roberto Firmino, Mohamed Salah and Sadio Mane compared to Ferguson's vintage which featured Wayne Rooney, Cristiano Ronaldo and Carlos Tevez.

(Image: Getty Images)

(Image: REUTERS)

But while it remains to be seen whether the German has built a team in the Scot's image, what has Klopp said about Ferguson in the past?

We've picked out some words from the archives.

December 2015, after Ferguson presented him with a Performance of the Week award following a 6-1 League Cup win at Southampton

(Image: REUTERS)

"He said congratulations and the rest is private.

"But I’ve had the huge honour of meeting him a few times and of course he is a role model for every manager in football.

"It was a big pleasure because he’s a funny person and something like a book of history in football so it was good to spend some time with him."

May 2018, on comparisons between Ferguson's United and his Liverpool side

(Image: X03807)

“Is there something with Alex Ferguson, Man United? At a specific time, they scored always twice.

“Score, score. That is the opportunity. Score once, do it again. Use the momentum in the game. Of course we talk about it, of course we want to use that, but you still have to score.

“The team is a really enthusiastic team. In a good moment, they jump and that’s really good to see.

(Image: Getty Images,)

"On the other hand, that’s why the two Man City games (in the Champions League quarter-finals) were really special. We dealt with the very difficult circumstances in the two halves here and there on a high level.

“That brought us to the semis, not that we can score one, two, three in a row. In the moments when we are not in charge of the game, we are still in the game, that’s a very important thing and that helped us massively.”

February 2019, ahead of last season's trip to Old Trafford

(Image: Getty Images)

“He is one of the biggest, if not the biggest, in world football.

“You can say that with all the things he achieved. Where he started, where he came from and what he did with the club. All that stuff. It’s just incredible.

“As a young manager – a couple of years ago I was a young manager – it’s not allowed to compare yourself or think about what he is doing and then compare to what you’re doing. It was a completely different world. It’s a different job.

“I always admired him. From a distance it’s easy. I’m not sure how it would have been if I was here 20 years at Liverpool and you always have this battle all the time.

(Image: Action Images)

Then maybe it’s different because he was a very competitive guy saying some things before he played against Liverpool.

“I’m pretty sure when he was in charge he didn’t want us [Liverpool] to be successful.

"Maybe he doesn’t want that now but the opinion is probably not that strong anymore because he said already a couple of times, I heard, that he likes what we are doing here.”
description: The German has always been a keen admirer of the United legend, as he takes his side to Old Trafford this weekend
